case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 66 and 67 of 1964 are appeals from the judgment and decree dated March 28, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 165 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 66 and 67 of 1964. Appeals from the judgment and decree March 28, 1961 of the Allahabad High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 165 of 1954.

facts.text: Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. carries on the business of manufacturing jute goods and is a member of the Jute Mills Association.

anchor.surface_text: The Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills Ltd. carries on the business of manufacturing jute goods and is a member of the Jute Mills Association.

facts.text: Members of the Jute Mills Association entered into an agreement dated January 9, 1932 called the First Working Time Agreement restricting hours of work, to expire on December 11, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: To protect the members against loss resulting from overproduction, members of the Association entered into an agreement dated January 9, 1932 called the First Working Time Agreement restricting hours of work. That agreement was to expire on December 11, 1944.

facts.text: A fresh agreement was executed on June 12, 1944 to continue the arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: With a view to continue the arrangement, a fresh agreement was executed on June 12, 1944.

facts.text: The agreement imposed restrictions upon the hours of work of its members via loom-hours allotment depending on number of looms installed.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 4 of the agreement, the association imposed restrictions upon the hours of work of its members. The number of hours for which the members were entitled to work their factories were called loom-hours. Allotment of loom-hours depended upon the number of looms installed in the factory of each member.

facts.text: The respondent was allotted 220 x 72 loom-hours per week under the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was under the agreement allotted 220 x 72 hours per week.

facts.text: In the account year corresponding to assessment year 1949-50, the preparatory section of the respondent's factory was unable to work the looms for more than 48 hours a week.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year corresponding to the assessment year 1949-50, the preparatory section of the factory of the respondent was unable to work the looms for more than 48 hours a week,

facts.text: With sanction of the Association, the respondent sold 220 x 24 loom-hours to Naskarpara Jute Mills and received Rs. 53,460 as consideration.

anchor.surface_text: and with the sanction of the Association the respondent sold 220 x 24 loom-hours to the Naskarpara Jute Mills and as consideration of. the sale received Rs. 53,460/-

facts.text: In the account year corresponding to assessment year 1950-51, the respondent received Rs. 1,85,230 from Birla Jute Mills and Hanuman Jute Mills for sale of surplus loom-hours.

anchor.surface_text: In the account year corresponding to the assessment year 1950-51 the respontdent received from the Birla Jute Mills and Hanuman Jute Mills a total amount of Rs. 1,85,230/- for sale of surplus loom-hours.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer included the amounts received by sale of loom-hours in the respondent's total income as revenue receipts liable to tax for assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment for the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Income-tax Officer included in the total income of the respondent the amounts received by sale of loom-hours as revenue receipts liable to tax.

facts.text: Order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer was confirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: At the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the question to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad

facts.text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the negative.

facts.text: The Commissioner of Income-tax preferred these appeals with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66A(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has preferred these appeals with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66-A (2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that the receipts in question were not capital receipts, nor were they of a casual or non-recurring nature.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held that the receipts in question were not capital receipts, nor were they of a casual or non- recurring nature.

facts.text: The respondent claimed that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax as casual and non-recurring under s. 4(3)(vii).

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 (3) (vii) , casual and non-recurring, has no substance.

facts.text: It is not the case of the Department that a business in loom-hours was carried on by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is not the case of the Department that a business in loom-hours was carried on by the respondent.

facts.text: The case has been considered on the footing that loom-hours are an asset capable of being transferred subject to sanction of the Association.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the Income-tax authorities the Tribunal and the High Court, these loom- hours have been regarded as an asset belonging to each member and in considering these appeals we do not think we would be justified allowing counsel to raise a contention  as was sought to be-done  that loom-hours were in the nature of a privilege and were not an asset at all.

facts.text: The respondent was unable, on account of inefficiency of its preparatory section, to supply the requisite material for running the factory for 72 hours per week.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was unable, on account of inefficiency of its preparatory section, to supply the requisite material for running the factory for 72 hours per week which it was entitled to do.

facts.text: The High Court held that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were capital receipts and not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were not taxable.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax decided on September 13, 1962 that payments for sale of loom-hours were taxable as business profit.

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was invited to a judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Maheshwari Devi Jute Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow 2  in which a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court answered a similar question relating to taxability of payments received for sale of loom-hours by the respondent in an assessment year with which we are not concerned in these appeals.
The Commissioner of Income-tax has preferred these appeals with certificate granted by the High Court under s. 66-A (2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the receipts of the assessee by the sale of loom-hours amounting to Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- in the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 respectively were revenue receipts liable to tax under the Indian Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the receipts of the assessee by the sale of loom-hours amounting to Rs. 53,460/- and Rs. 1,85,230/- in the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51 respectively were revenue receipts liable to tax under the Indian

issues.text: Whether the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4(3)(vii), casual and non-recurring?

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 (3) (vii) , casual and non-recurring, has nosubstance.

issues.text: Whether where it is a part of the normal activity of the assessee's business to earn profit by making use of its asset by either employing it in its own manufacturing concern or by letting it out to others, consideration received for allowing the transferee to use that asset is income received from business?

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General submitted that where it is a part of the normal activity of the assessees business to earn profit by making use of its asset by either employing it in its own manufacturing concern Dr by letting it out to others, consideration received for allowing the transferee to use that asset is income received from business and chargeable to income-tax.

issues.text: Whether the loom-hours allotted constitute fixed capital assets of the assessee such that their sale results in a capital receipt?

anchor.surface_text: Distinction between revenue and capital in the law of income-tax is fundamental. Tax is ordinarily not levied on capital profits it is levied on income. It is well-settled that sale of stock-in-trade or circulating capital or rendering service in the course of trading results in a trading receipt sale of assets which the assessee uses as fixed capital to enable him to carry on his business results in capital receipt.

issues.text: Whether loom-hours are an asset capable of being transferred or merely a privilege?

Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P., Lucknow 2  in which a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court answered a similar question relating to taxability of payments received for sale of loom-hours by the respondent in an assessment year with which we are not concerned in these appeals. The Court in that case ignoring the view in the judgments under appeal held that loom-hours did number form the fixed profit-making structure of the respondent

arguments.claim: Sale of assets used as fixed capital to carry on business results in capital receipt; loom-hours are such fixed capital

anchor.surface_text: Distinction between revenue and capital in the law of income-tax is fundamental. Tax is ordinarily number levied on capital profits it is levied on income. It is well-settLed that sale of stock-in-trade or circulating capital or rendering service in the companyrse of trading results in a trading receipt sale of assets which the assessee uses as fixed capital to enable him to carry on his business results in capital receipt.

arguments.claim: Transaction in loom-hours is sale, not letting out; cannot grant temporary right to use loom-hours while retaining property

anchor.surface_text: What was let out in Lakshmi Silk Mills case 1  was the dyeing plant which companytinued to remain the property of the Company and it was temporarily let out when the assessee was unable to use it. Receipt from a companymercial asset when it is capable of being used by the assessee but is number so used because of circumstances which necessitate lesser of its use would undoubtedly be income, where the asset remains the property of the assessee and user of the asset is given to another person. If in the present case, for the hours which the respondent was unable to use its looms the respondent had permitted some other person to work the looms, profits received for permitting such user would be income. But the distinction between that case and the present case arises from the peculiar nature of the transaction in loom- hours. Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them, for there can be numbergrant of a temporary right to use loom-hours.

arguments.claim: No compensation paid for restraint of trade; facility to transfer loom-hours provided by Association

anchor.surface_text: It is number the case of the Department that a business in loom-hours was carried on by the respondent. It is also companymon ground that for imposing restrictions upon the number of working hours, numbercompensation was paid to the members by the association or by any other body if it were, such companypensation being paid for agreeing to restraint on trade would be capital.

holdings.text: The receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were not taxable

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were not taxable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loom-hours are fixed capital assets; outright sale divests ownership unlike temporary letting out; distinguishes Lakshmi Silk Mills; rejects alternative views

holdings.text: The plea that receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax as casual and non-recurring under s. 4(3)(vii) has no substance

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 (3) (vii) , casual and non-recurring, has no substance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exemption under s.4(3)(vii) does not apply to receipts in ordinary course of business even if casual/non-recurring; also these are capital gains excludable anyway

holdings.text: Loom-hours have been regarded as an asset belonging to each member; not justified to raise contention that they were merely a privilege and not an asset

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the Income-tax authorities the Tribunal and the High Court, these loom- hours have been regarded as an asset belonging to each member and in considering these appeals we do not think we would be justified allowing counsel to raise a contention  as was sought to be-done  that loom-hours were in the nature of a privilege and were not an asset at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consistent treatment in lower proceedings as transferable asset; court declines to permit new contention diverging from that footing

holdings.text: Sale of assets which the assessee uses as fixed capital to enable him to carry on his business results in capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that sale of stock-in-trade or circulating capital or rendering service in the course of trading results in a trading receipt sale of assets which the assessee uses as fixed capital to enable him to carry on his business results in capital receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled distinction between fixed capital (capital receipt on sale) and circulating capital/stock-in-trade (revenue receipt); applies to loom-hours as fixed capital

holdings.text: Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them; transaction is outright sale not temporary user

anchor.surface_text: Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them, for there can be no grant of a temporary right to use loom-hours. Loom-hours are the asset of the respondent, but temporary user of the loom-hours cannot be granted. The transaction in this case is of sale of loom-hours.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Peculiar nature of loom-hours precludes letting out with retained ownership unlike physical assets; distinguishes from Shri Lakshmi Silk Mills where plant remained property

holdings.text: It is not the case of the Department that a business in loom-hours was carried on by the respondent

anchor.surface_text: It is not the case of the Department that a business in loom-hours was carried on by the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission by petitioner; no claim of trading in loom-hours

holdings.text: Such compensation being paid for agreeing to restraint on trade would be capital but no compensation was paid here

anchor.surface_text: It is also common ground that for imposing restrictions upon the number of working hours, no compensation was paid to the members by the association or by any other body if it were, such compensation being paid for agreeing to restraint on trade would be capital.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground no compensation paid; obiter on nature if it were

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the view that sale of surplus loom-hours amounted to exploitation of capital asset yielding business profit

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with this view. The surplus loom-hours were disposed of and no interest remained therein with the respondent there was no exploitation of the loom-hours by permitting user while retaining ownership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects other Allahabad HC view for different year; no retained interest post-sale

precedents.cited_proposition: Receipt by the exploitation of a commercial asset is the profit of the business, irrespective of the manner in which the asset is exploited by the owner of the business, whether by using it himself or letting it out to others
precedents.cited_holding: an asset acquired and used for the purpose of the business does not cease to be a commercial asset of that business as soon as it is temporarily put out of use or is let out to another person for use in his business or trade

anchor.surface_text: The plea of the respondent that the receipts for sale of loom-hours are not chargeable to tax because they are, within the meaning of s. 4 (3) (vii) , casual and non-recurring, has no substance.
In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were number taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In the proceedings before the Income-tax authorities the Tribunal and the High Court, these loom- hours have been regarded as an asset belonging to each member and in considering these appeals we do not think we would be justified allowing counsel to raise a contention  as was sought to be-done  that loom-hours were in the nature of a privilege and were not an asset at all.
In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were number taxable.

anchor.surface_text: Loom-hours cannot from their very nature be let out while retaining property in them, for there can be no grant of a temporary right to use loom-hours. Loom-hours are the asset of the respondent, but temporary user of the loom-hours cannot be granted. The transaction in this case is of sale of loom-hours.
In our judgment the High Court was right in holding that the receipts from sale of loom-hours were in the nature of capital receipts and were number taxable.
